ud8.7:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu addhānamaggappaṭipanno hoti āyasmatā nāgasamālena pacchāsamaṇena.
ud8.7:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was traveling along a road in the Kosalan lands with Venerable Nāgasamāla as his second monk.

ud8.7:1.3.pli: Addasā kho āyasmā nāgasamālo antarāmagge dvidhāpathaṃ.
ud8.7:1.3.eng: Nāgasamāla saw a fork in the road

ud8.7:1.7.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhagavā āyasmantaṃ nāgasamālaṃ etadavoca:
ud8.7:1.7.eng: But when he said this the Buddha responded,

ud8.7:2.2.pli: tatiyampi kho āyasmā nāgasamālo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
ud8.7:2.2.eng: and a third time Nāgasamāla said to the Buddha,

ud8.7:2.5.pli: Tatiyampi kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ nāgasamālaṃ etadavoca:
ud8.7:2.5.eng: And for a third time the Buddha responded,

ud8.7:2.8.pli: Atha kho āyasmā nāgasamālo bhagavato pattacīvaraṃ tattheva chamāyaṃ nikkhipitvā pakkāmi:
ud8.7:2.8.eng: Then Nāgasamāla put the Buddha’s bowl and robes down on the ground right there and left, saying,

ud8.7:2.9.eng: “Sir, here are your bowl and robes.”

ud8.7:3.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmato nāgasamālassa tena panthena gacchantassa antarāmagge corā nikkhamitvā hatthehi ca pādehi ca ākoṭesuṃ pattañca bhindiṃsu saṅghāṭiñca vipphālesuṃ.
ud8.7:3.1.eng: Then as Nāgasamāla was going down that road, he was set upon by bandits who struck him with fists and feet, broke his bowl, and tore up his outer robe.

ud8.7:3.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā nāgasamālo bhinnena pattena vipphālitāya saṅghāṭiyā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
ud8.7:3.2.eng: Then Nāgasamāla—with his bowl broken and his outer robe torn—went to the Buddha and told him what had happened.

ud8.7:3.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā nāgasamālo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

ud8.7:3.4.pli: “idha mayhaṃ, bhante, tena panthena gacchantassa antarāmagge corā nikkhamitvā hatthehi ca pādehi ca ākoṭesuṃ, pattañca bhindiṃsu, saṅghāṭiñca vipphālesun”ti.

ud8.7:4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud8.7:4.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud8.7:5.2.eng: the knowledge master mixes with foolish folk.

ud8.7:5.3.eng: Knowing this, they give up wickedness,

ud8.7:5.4.eng: like a milk-drinking heron the water.”

ud8.8:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati pubbārāme migāramātupāsāde.
ud8.8:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother in the Eastern Monastery.

ud8.8:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena visākhāya migāramātuyā nattā kālaṅkatā hoti piyā manāpā.
ud8.8:1.3.eng: Now at that time the dear and beloved granddaughter of Visākhā Migāra’s Mother had just passed away.

ud8.8:1.4.pli: Atha kho visākhā migāramātā allavatthā allakesā divā divassa yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
ud8.8:1.4.eng: Then, in the middle of the day, Visākhā with wet clothes and hair went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down.

ud8.8:1.5.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho visākhaṃ migāramātaraṃ bhagavā etadavoca:

ud8.8:2.1.pli: “Handa kuto nu tvaṃ, visākhe, āgacchasi allavatthā allakesā idhūpasaṅkantā divā divassā”ti?
ud8.8:2.1.eng: “So, Visākhā, where are you coming from in the middle of the day with wet clothes and hair?”

ud8.8:2.2.eng: “Sir, my beloved granddaughter has just passed away.

ud8.8:2.3.pli: Tenāhaṃ allavatthā allakesā idhūpasaṅkantā divā divassā”ti.
ud8.8:2.3.eng: That’s why I came here in the middle of the day with wet clothes and hair.”

ud8.8:2.4.pli: “Iccheyyāsi tvaṃ, visākhe, yāvatikā sāvatthiyā manussā tāvatike putte ca nattāro cā”ti?
ud8.8:2.4.eng: “Visākhā, would you like as many children and grandchildren as there are people in the whole of Sāvatthī?”

ud8.8:2.5.pli: “Iccheyyāhaṃ, bhagavā, yāvatikā sāvatthiyā manussā tāvatike putte ca nattāro cā”ti.

ud8.8:3.1.pli: “Kīvabahukā pana, visākhe, sāvatthiyā manussā devasikaṃ kālaṃ karontī”ti?
ud8.8:3.1.eng: “But Visākhā, how many people pass away each day in Sāvatthī?”

ud8.8:3.2.pli: “Dasapi, bhante, sāvatthiyā manussā devasikaṃ kālaṃ karonti;
ud8.8:3.2.eng: “Every day, sir, there are ten people passing away in Sāvatthī.

ud8.8:3.10.pli: dvepi, bhante, sāvatthiyā manussā devasikaṃ kālaṃ karonti.

ud8.8:3.11.pli: Ekopi, bhante, sāvatthiyā manusso devasikaṃ kālaṃ karoti.
ud8.8:3.11.eng: or at least one person who passes away every day in Sāvatthī.

ud8.8:3.12.pli: Avivittā, bhante, sāvatthi manussehi kālaṃ karontehī”ti.
ud8.8:3.12.eng: Sāvatthī is never without someone passing away.”

ud8.8:4.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, visākhe, api nu tvaṃ kadāci karahaci anallavatthā vā bhaveyyāsi anallakesā vā”ti?
ud8.8:4.1.eng: “What do you think, Visākhā? Would there ever be a time when your clothes and hair were not wet?”

ud8.8:4.3.pli: Alaṃ me, bhante, tāva bahukehi puttehi ca nattārehi cā”ti.
ud8.8:4.3.eng: Enough, sir, with so many children and grandchildren.”

ud8.8:5.1.pli: “Yesaṃ kho, visākhe, sataṃ piyāni, sataṃ tesaṃ dukkhāni;
ud8.8:5.1.eng: “Those who have a hundred loved ones, Visākhā, have a hundred sufferings.

ud8.8:5.2.pli: yesaṃ navuti piyāni, navuti tesaṃ dukkhāni;
ud8.8:5.2.eng: Those who have ninety loved ones,

ud8.8:5.3.pli: yesaṃ asīti piyāni, asīti tesaṃ dukkhāni;

ud8.8:5.4.pli: yesaṃ sattati piyāni, sattati tesaṃ dukkhāni;

ud8.8:5.5.pli: yesaṃ saṭṭhi piyāni, saṭṭhi tesaṃ dukkhāni;

ud8.8:5.6.pli: yesaṃ paññāsaṃ piyāni, paññāsaṃ tesaṃ dukkhāni;

ud8.8:5.7.pli: yesaṃ cattārīsaṃ piyāni, cattārīsaṃ tesaṃ dukkhāni,

ud8.8:5.8.pli: yesaṃ tiṃsaṃ piyāni, tiṃsaṃ tesaṃ dukkhāni;

ud8.8:5.9.pli: yesaṃ vīsati piyāni, vīsati tesaṃ dukkhāni,

ud8.8:5.10.pli: yesaṃ dasa piyāni, dasa tesaṃ dukkhāni;

ud8.8:5.11.pli: yesaṃ nava piyāni, nava tesaṃ dukkhāni;

ud8.8:5.12.pli: yesaṃ aṭṭha piyāni, aṭṭha tesaṃ dukkhāni;

ud8.8:5.13.pli: yesaṃ satta piyāni, satta tesaṃ dukkhāni;

ud8.8:5.14.pli: yesaṃ cha piyāni, cha tesaṃ dukkhāni;

ud8.8:5.15.pli: yesaṃ pañca piyāni, pañca tesaṃ dukkhāni;

ud8.8:5.16.pli: yesaṃ cattāri piyāni, cattāri tesaṃ dukkhāni;

ud8.8:5.17.pli: yesaṃ tīṇi piyāni, tīṇi tesaṃ dukkhāni;

ud8.8:5.18.pli: yesaṃ dve piyāni, dve tesaṃ dukkhāni;

ud8.8:5.19.pli: yesaṃ ekaṃ piyaṃ, ekaṃ tesaṃ dukkhaṃ;
ud8.8:5.19.eng: or one loved one have one suffering.

ud8.8:5.20.pli: yesaṃ natthi piyaṃ, natthi tesaṃ dukkhaṃ, asokā te virajā anupāyāsāti vadāmī”ti.
ud8.8:5.20.eng: Those who have no loved ones have no suffering. They are free of sorrow, stains, and anguish I say.”

ud8.8:6.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud8.8:6.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud8.8:7.2.eng: and the countless forms of suffering in the world

ud8.8:7.3.eng: occur because of those that we love;

ud8.8:7.4.eng: without loved ones they do not occur.

ud8.8:8.1.eng: That’s why those who have no loved ones <j>at all in the world

ud8.8:8.2.eng: are happy and free of grief.

ud8.8:8.3.eng: So aspiring to the sorrowless and stainless,

ud8.8:8.4.eng: have no loved ones in the world at all.”

ud8.9:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
ud8.9:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

ud8.9:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā dabbo mallaputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
ud8.9:1.3.eng: Then Venerable Dabba the Mallian went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

ud8.9:1.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā dabbo mallaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

ud8.9:1.5.eng: “Holy One, it is the time for my full extinguishment.”

ud8.9:1.6.eng: “Please, Dabba, do as you see fit.”

ud8.9:2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā dabbo mallaputto uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā vehāsaṃ abbhuggantvā ākāse antalikkhe pallaṅkena nisīditvā tejodhātuṃ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhahitvā parinibbāyi.
ud8.9:2.1.eng: Then Dabba rose from his seat, bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right. Then he rose into the air and, sitting cross-legged in midair, entered and withdrew from the fire element before becoming fully extinguished.

ud8.9:3.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmato dabbassa mallaputtassa vehāsaṃ abbhuggantvā ākāse antalikkhe pallaṅkena nisīditvā tejodhātuṃ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhahitvā parinibbutassa sarīrassa jhāyamānassa ḍayhamānassa neva chārikā paññāyittha na masi.
ud8.9:3.1.eng: Then when he was fully quenched while sitting cross-legged in midair, his body burning and combusting left neither ashes nor soot to be found.

ud8.9:3.2.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma sappissa vā telassa vā jhāyamānassa ḍayhamānassa neva chārikā paññāyati na masi;
ud8.9:3.2.eng: It’s like when ghee or oil blaze and burn, and neither ashes nor soot are found.

ud8.9:3.3.pli: evamevaṃ āyasmato dabbassa mallaputtassa vehāsaṃ abbhuggantvā ākāse antalikkhe pallaṅkena nisīditvā tejodhātuṃ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhahitvā parinibbutassa sarīrassa jhāyamānassa ḍayhamānassa neva chārikā paññāyittha na masīti.

ud8.9:4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud8.9:4.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud8.9:5.1.eng: “The body is broken up, perception has ceased,

ud8.9:5.4.eng: and consciousness come to an end.”
